body.p: The purpose of this activity is to give you guided practice in carrying out the paired t-test and to teach you how to obtain the paired t-test output using statistical software. Here is some background for the historically important data that we are going to work with in this activity.

William S. Gosset was employed by the Guinness brewing company of Dublin. Sample sizes available for experimentation in brewing were necessarily small, and new techniques for handling the resulting data were needed. Gosset consulted Karl Pearson (1857-1936) of University College in London, who told him that the current state of knowledge was unsatisfactory. Gosset undertook a course of study under Pearson and the outcome of his study was perhaps the most famous paper in statistical literature, "The Probable Error of a Mean" (1908), which introduced the t distribution.
Since Gosset was contractually bound by Guinness, he published under a pseudonym, "Student"; hence, the t distribution is often referred to as Student's t distribution.

As an example to illustrate his analysis, Gosset reported in his paper on the results of seeding 11 different plots of land with two different types of seed: regular and kiln-dried. There is reason to believe that drying seeds before planting will increase plant yield. Since different plots of soil may be naturally more fertile, this confounding variable was eliminated by using the matched pairs design and planting both types of seed in all 11 plots.
The resulting data (corn yield in pounds per acre) are as follows:
We use these data to test the hypothesis that kiln-dried seed yields more corn than regular seed. Here is a figure that summarizes this problem:

image.alt: Our categorical explanatory variable is Seed Type (X), with categories regular and kiln dried. Using this, we create Population 1: plots planted with regular seeds, and Population 2: plots planted with kiln-dried seeds. For each population, there is a corn yield (Y) mean μ_1 and μ_2. When we create an SRS for each population, we are using the same plots in both samples, thus using a matched pair design. Each SRS has a size 11.

body.p: Because of the nature of the experimental design (matched pairs), we are testing the difference in yield.
Note that the differences were calculated: regular − kiln-dried.

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To open R with the data set preloaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in R.
The data have been loaded into the data frame seed. Enter the command seed to see the data. The variables in the data frame are regular.seed and kiln.dried.seed.
To carry out the paired t-test, use the following command:

The mean of the differences is provided in the output in addition to the other pertinent information. Notice that the order of the variables indicates the order of the difference calculation (position 1 − position 2).

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To open this file in StatCrunch you must first right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Next click here to open StatCrunch in a separate window and login using your username and password.

ul.li: Click on the link "Open StatCrunch" at the top of the My StatCrunch page.
To open the data set, click on the Data button in the top row and select Load → From file → on my computer.
Under File, press the Browse button and select the data set you downloaded.
Scroll to the bottom of the page and click on "Load File."

alternative.p: Please use the following StatCrunch commands to answer the next set of questions:

ul.li: Choose: Stat → T Stats → Paired.
Select Regular seed for Sample 1.
Select Kiln-dried seed for Sample 2.
For Save, check "Differences."

In Perform, select Hypothesis test for
μ d
=
μ 1
−
μ 2
.

Enter a null value for
μ d
.
For the alternative hypothesis, choose from the options of not equal, less than and greater than (be sure to consider how the differences were calculated).
Press Compute!

alternative.p: Note that the computed differences appear in a new column called Differences.

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To open Minitab with the data in the worksheet, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Minitab. Note: a dialog box will likely appear that says "A copy of the content of this file will be added to the current project"—just click "OK."
The following Minitab commands will be needed for the next questions:

p.em: I. Creating a column of differences

ul.li: Choose Calc → Calculator.
Ask Minitab to store the result in the next available column.
Under "Expression," type c1-c2 (the expression that will create the desired differences).
Click "OK."
Name the newly created column "Differences."

p.em: II. Carrying out the paired t-test

ul.li: Choose Stat → Basic Statistics → Paired t.
Choose "Samples in column" and enter the columns where the samples are.
Under "Options," set the appropriate alternative.
Click "OK" twice.

alternative.title: Excel 2007 Instructions
alternative.p: To open Excel with the data in the worksheet, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel.
The following Excel commands will be needed for the next questions:

ul.li: In column C, type the following formula in each of the cells in rows 2-12: =A1-B1, adjusting the row numbers accordingly.
Name the newly created column Differences.
Choose Data Analysis from the Analysis group in the Data tab. In the pop-up window, choose t-Test: Paired Two Sample for Means.
In the next window, enter the data for column A next to Variable 1 Range and the data for column B next to Variable 2 Range.
Click "OK."

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: Enter the Regular seed data in L1.
Enter the Kiln-dried seed data in L2.

ul.li: Calculate the difference between each pair of values.
Store these differences in a list.
Go to the Home Screen by pressing QUIT (2ND/MODE).
Enter L1-L2 STO> L3, using these steps:
Choose L1 (2ND/1).
Press – (the subtraction key).
Choose L2 (2ND/2).
Press STO> (the store key above the ON key).
Choose L3 (2ND/3).
Press ENTER.
Choose STAT/TESTS/2:T-Test.
Choose Data.
Enter 0 for the null value for the difference in means (used in null hypothesis).
Then enter the List: where the differences are stored.
List:L3 (2ND/ 3).
Freq:1 (The number 1).
Choose the appropriate form of the alternative hypothesis (≠, <, >).
Choose Calculate, then press ENTER.
